# Introduction

## Purpose

To rotate the IP address for a given adapter at a specified interval.

## Introductory note

This document was created for 'Wikyd World Wide' (http://WikydWorldWide.com) to be used as a guide to the IP Rotation tool.

## Compatibilities

This tool is intended for use on CentOS 5 32-bit. Its has also been tested CentOS 4, and the RHEL equivalents, as well as 64-bit systems. It has not been fully tested on Debian or Slackware systems but can be made to work with small modifications to the service file and locations of the configuration files.

# Description

## Files:

### /etc/init.d/rotation

service script that handles the execution and running of the process

### /etc/sysconfig/rotation-config

contains variables controlling the behavior of the service

### /etc/sysconfig/rotation-ips

contains a list of IP addresses to rotate

### /usr/local/bin/rotation

executable bash file called by service script to performs the rotation

# Operation:

## Starting & stopping the service:

<tt class="western">service rotation stop</tt> or <tt class="western">/etc/init.d/rotation stop</tt>

<tt class="western">service rotation start</tt> or <tt class="western">/etc/init.d/rotation start</tt>

<tt class="western">service rotation status</tt> or <tt class="western">/etc/init.d/rotation status</tt>

## Installing/un-installing the service:

<tt class="western">chkconfig rotation off</tt>

<tt class="western">chkconfig rotation on</tt>

## Changing the configuration:

Edit the file: <tt class="western">/etc/sysconfig/rotation-config</tt>

This contains 2 variables: interface and interval.

Interface is the physical interface used for the rotation: e.g. eth0, eth1\.

Virtual interfaces are also supported eg: eth0:1, eth1:12\.

Specify as follows:

<tt class="western">interface=eth1</tt>

The interval specifies the time in minutes between each rotation.

Specify as follows:

<tt class="western">interval=30</tt>

which specifies a 30 minute delay between each interval.

**Note that everything in this file is case sensitive.**

## IP Addresses:

To change the IP addresses used for the rotation, simply add each IP address to the file: <tt class="western">/etc/sysconfig/rotation-ips</tt> – one per line, and remove any IP addresses you wish to exclude.

You may also choose to temporarily exclude an IP address. This can be done by adding a “#” hash character to the beginning of the line to turn it into a comment: for example:

<tt class="western">#192.168.0.1</tt>

After any changes are made to the config, you need to restart the service for changes to take affect:

<tt class="western">service rotation restart</tt>

## <tt class="western"><font face="Arial Black"><span style="font-style: normal"><span style="font-weight: normal">Logging:</span></span></font></tt>

<tt class="western"><font face="Times New Roman, serif"><span style="font-style: normal"><span style="font-weight: normal">All logging will appear in the file</span> </span></font></tt><tt class="western"><font face="Bitstream Vera Sans, sans-serif">_<span style="font-weight: normal">/var/log/messages</span>_</font></tt><tt class="western"><font face="Times New Roman, serif"><span style="font-style: normal"> <span style="font-weight: normal">in the following format:</span></span></font></tt>

<tt class="western"><font face="Bitstream Vera Sans, sans-serif">Dec 9 12:02:35 localhost rotation[27599]: IP address changed to: 208.91.201.11</font></tt>
